abstract.p: William W Fick letter says capital punishment in United States has become punishment systematically wielded against the disadvantaged (July 10 James Q Wilson Op-Ed)

block.p: James Q. Wilson misses the point with his blithe observation that ''no one has shown that innocent people are being executed'' (''What Death-Penalty Errors?'', Op-Ed, July 10).
James Q. Wilson misses the point with his blithe observation that ''no one has shown that innocent people are being executed'' (''What Death-Penalty Errors?'', Op-Ed, July 10).

The real scandal and tragedy of capital punishment in this country lies not in the specter of innocents condemned but rather in the way that we choose, from among the guilty, who ''deserves'' the ultimate penalty. Far from an extreme sanction reserved only for the most heinous crimes and culpable defendants, the death penalty has become a device wielded against society's outcasts, systematically disadvantaged by reason of race, poverty or mental impairment.
This is cause for a wave of indignation, not a reason to ''calm down,'' as Mr. Wilson suggests.
WILLIAM W. FICK Woodbridge, Conn., July 10, 2000
